QAPair.Question: What is (are) Spasmus nutans ?
QAPair.Answer: Spasmus nutans is a disorder affecting infants and young children. It involves rapid, uncontrolled eye movements, head bobbing, and sometimes, holding the neck in an abnormal position.

QAPair.Question: What causes Spasmus nutans ?
QAPair.Answer: Most cases of spasmus nutans begin between age 6 months and 1 year. It usually lasts about 2 years but can go on as long as 5 years. The cause is unknown, although it may be associated with other medical conditions. A link with iron or vitamin D deficiency has been suggested. In very rare cases, symptoms similar to spasmus nutans may be due to certain types of brain tumors or other serious conditions.

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Spasmus nutans ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms of spasmus nutans include: Small, quick, side-to-side eye movements called nystagmus (both eyes are involved, but each eye may move differently), Head nodding, Head tilting ,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Spasmus nutans ?
QAPair.Answer: Your health care provider will perform a physical exam of your child. You may be asked about your child's symptoms. Tests may include: CT scan of the head , MRI scan of the head , Electroretinography , a test that measures the electrical response of the retina (the back part of the eye),

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Spasmus nutans ?
QAPair.Answer: Spasmus nutans that isn't related to another medical problem, such as brain tumor, requires no treatment. If the symptoms are caused by another condition, your provider will recommend appropriate treatment.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Spasmus nutans ?
QAPair.Answer: Usually, this disorder goes away on its own without treatment.

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Spasmus nutans ?
QAPair.Answer: Call for an appointment with your child's provider if your child has rapid, movements of the eyes, or head nodding. The provider will need to perform an exam to rule out other possible causes for the symptoms.
